author: Grimms
text: A certain father had two sons, the elder of who was smart and sensible, and could do everything, but the younger was stupid and could neither learn nor understand anything, and when people saw him they said: "There"s a fellow who will give his father some trouble!"

author: Grimms
text: When anything had to be done, it was always the elder who was forced to do it; but if his father bade him fetch anything when it was late, or in the night-time, and the way led through the churchyard, or any other dismal place, he answered: "Oh, no father, I"ll not go there, it makes me shudder!" for he was afraid.

author: Grimms
text: Or when stories were told by the fire at night which made the flesh creep, the listeners sometimes said: "Oh, it makes us shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: The younger sat in a corner and listened with the rest of them, and could not imagine what they could mean.

author: Grimms
text: "They are always saying: "It makes me shudder, it makes me shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: It does not make me shudder," thought he.

author: Grimms
text: "That, too, must be an art of which I understand nothing!"

author: Grimms
text: Now it came to pass that his father said to him one day: "Hearken to me, you fellow in the corner there, you are growing tall and strong, and you too must learn something by which you can earn your bread.

author: Grimms
text: Look how your brother works, but you do not even earn your salt."

author: Grimms
text: "Well, father," he replied, "I am quite willing to learn something-- indeed, if it could but be managed, I should like to learn how to shudder.

author: Grimms
text: I don"t understand that at all yet."

author: Grimms
text: The elder brother smiled when he heard that, and thought to himself: "Goodness, what a blockhead that brother of mine is!

author: Grimms
text: He will never be good for anything as long as he lives!

author: Grimms
text: He who wants to be a sickle must bend himself betimes."

author: Grimms
text: The father sighed, and answered him: "You shall soon learn what it is to shudder, but you will not earn your bread by that."

author: Grimms
text: Soon after this the sexton came to the house on a visit, and the father bewailed his trouble, and told him how his younger son was so backward in every respect that he knew nothing and learnt nothing.

author: Grimms
text: "Just think," said he, "when I asked him how he was going to earn his bread, he actually wanted to learn to shudder."

author: Grimms
text: "If that be all," replied the sexton, "he can learn that with me.

author: Grimms
text: Send him to me, and I will soon polish him."

author: Grimms
text: The father was glad to do it, for he thought: "It will train the boy a little."

author: Grimms
text: The sexton therefore took him into his house, and he had to ring the church bell.

author: Grimms
text: After a day or two, the sexton awoke him at midnight, and bade him arise and go up into the church tower and ring the bell.

author: Grimms
text: "You shall soon learn what shuddering is," thought he, and secretly went there before him; and when the boy was at the top of the tower and turned round, and was just going to take hold of the bell rope, he saw a white figure standing on the stairs opposite the sounding hole.

author: Grimms
text: "Who is there?" cried he, but the figure made no reply, and did not move or stir.

author: Grimms
text: "Give an answer," cried the boy, "or take yourself off, you have no business here at night."

author: Grimms
text: The sexton, however, remained standing motionless that the boy might think he was a ghost.

author: Grimms
text: The boy cried a second time: "What do you want here?--speak if you are an honest fellow, or I will throw you down the steps!"

author: Grimms
text: The sexton thought: "He can"t mean to be as bad as his words," uttered no sound and stood as if he were made of stone.

author: Grimms
text: Then the boy called to him for the third time, and as that was also to no purpose, he ran against him and pushed the ghost down the stairs, so that it fell down the ten steps and remained lying there in a corner.

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon he rang the bell, went home, and without saying a word went to bed, and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
text: The sexton"s wife waited a long time for her husband, but he did not come back.

author: Grimms
text: At length she became uneasy, and wakened the boy, and asked: "Do you know where my husband is?

author: Grimms
text: He climbed up the tower before you did."

author: Grimms
text: "No, I don"t know," replied the boy, "but someone was standing by the sounding hole on the other side of the steps, and as he would neither gave an answer nor go away, I took him for a scoundrel, and threw him downstairs.

author: Grimms
text: Just go there and you will see if it was he.

author: Grimms
text: I should be sorry if it were."

author: Grimms
text: The woman ran away and found her husband, who was lying moaning in the corner, and had broken his leg.

author: Grimms
text: She carried him down, and then with loud screams she hastened to the boy"s father, "Your boy," cried she, "has been the cause of a great misfortune!

author: Grimms
text: He has thrown my husband down the steps so that he broke his leg.

author: Grimms
text: Take the good-for-nothing fellow out of our house."

author: Grimms
text: The father was terrified, and ran thither and scolded the boy.

author: Grimms
text: "What wicked tricks are these?" said he.

author: Grimms
text: "The devil must have put them into your head."

author: Grimms
text: "Father," he replied, "do listen to me.

author: Grimms
text: I am quite innocent.

author: Grimms
text: He was standing there by night like one intent on doing evil.

author: Grimms
text: I did not know who it was, and I entreated him three times either to speak or to go away."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah," said the father, "I have nothing but unhappiness with you.

author: Grimms
text: Go out of my sight.

author: Grimms
text: I will see you no more."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, father, right willingly, wait only until it is day.

author: Grimms
text: Then will I go forth and learn how to shudder, and then I shall, at any rate, understand one art which will support me."

author: Grimms
text: "Learn what you will," spoke the father, "it is all the same to me.

author: Grimms
text: Here are fifty talers for you.

author: Grimms
text: Take these and go into the wide world, and tell no one from whence you come, and who is your father, for I have reason to be ashamed of you."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, father, it shall be as you will.

author: Grimms
text: If you desire nothing more than that, I can easily keep it in mind."

author: Grimms
text: When the day dawned, therefore, the boy put his fifty talers into his pocket, and went forth on the great highway, and continually said to himself: "If I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
text: If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: Then a man approached who heard this conversation which the youth was holding with himself, and when they had walked a little farther to where they could see the gallows, the man said to him: "Look, there is the tree where seven men have married the ropemaker"s daughter, and are now learning how to fly.

author: Grimms
text: Sit down beneath it, and wait till night comes, and you will soon learn how to shudder."

author: Grimms
text: "If that is all that is wanted," answered the youth, "it is easily done; but if I learn how to shudder as fast as that, you shall have my fifty talers.

author: Grimms
text: Just come back to me early in the morning."

author: Grimms
text: Then the youth went to the gallows, sat down beneath it, and waited till evening came.

author: Grimms
text: And as he was cold, he lighted himself a fire, but at midnight the wind blew so sharply that in spite of his fire, he could not get warm.

author: Grimms
text: And as the wind knocked the hanged men against each other, and they moved backwards and forwards, he thought to himself: "If you shiver below by the fire, how those up above must freeze and suffer!"

author: Grimms
text: And as he felt pity for them, he raised the ladder, and climbed up, unbound one of them after the other, and brought down all seven.

author: Grimms
text: Then he stoked the fire, blew it, and set them all round it to warm themselves.

author: Grimms
text: But they sat there and did not stir, and the fire caught their clothes.

author: Grimms
text: So he said: "Take care, or I will hang you up again."

author: Grimms
text: The dead men, however, did not hear, but were quite silent, and let their rags go on burning.

author: Grimms
text: At this he grew angry, and said: "If you will not take care, I cannot help you, I will not be burnt with you," and he hung them up again each in his turn.

author: Grimms
text: Then he sat down by his fire and fell asleep, and the next morning the man came to him and wanted to have the fifty talers, and said: "Well do you know how to shudder?"

author: Grimms
text: "No," answered he, "how should I know?

author: Grimms
text: Those fellows up there did not open their mouths, and were so stupid that they let the few old rags which they had on their bodies get burnt."

author: Grimms
text: Then the man saw that he would not get the fifty talers that day, and went away saying: "Such a youth has never come my way before."

author: Grimms
text: The youth likewise went his way, and once more began to mutter to himself: "Ah, if I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
text: Ah, if I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: A waggoner who was striding behind him heard this and asked: "Who are you?"

author: Grimms
text: "I don"t know," answered the youth.

author: Grimms
text: Then the waggoner asked: "From whence do you come?"

author: Grimms
text: "I know not."

author: Grimms
text: "Who is your father?"

author: Grimms
text: "That I may not tell you."

author: Grimms
text: "What is it that you are always muttering between your teeth?"

author: Grimms
text: "Ah," replied the youth, "I do so wish I could shudder, but no one can teach me how."

author: Grimms
text: "Enough of your foolish chatter," said the waggoner.

author: Grimms
text: "Come, go with me, I will see about a place for you."

author: Grimms
text: The youth went with the waggoner, and in the evening they arrived at an inn where they wished to pass the night.

author: Grimms
text: Then at the entrance of the parlour the youth again said quite loudly: "If I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
text: If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: The host who heard this, laughed and said: "If that is your desire, there ought to be a good opportunity for you here."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, be silent," said the hostess, "so many prying persons have already lost their lives, it would be a pity and a shame if such beautiful eyes as these should never see the daylight again."

author: Grimms
text: But the youth said: "However difficult it may be, I will learn it.

author: Grimms
text: For this purpose indeed have I journeyed forth."

author: Grimms
text: He let the host have no rest, until the latter told him, that not far from thence stood a haunted castle where anyone could very easily learn what shuddering was, if he would but watch in it for three nights.

author: Grimms
text: The king had promised that he who would venture should have his daughter to wife, and she was the most beautiful maiden the sun shone on.

author: Grimms
text: Likewise in the castle lay great treasures, which were guarded by evil spirits, and these treasures would then be freed, and would make a poor man rich enough.

author: Grimms
text: Already many men had gone into the castle, but as yet none had come out again.

author: Grimms
text: Then the youth went next morning to the king, and said: "If it be allowed, I will willingly watch three nights in the haunted castle."

author: Grimms
text: The king looked at him, and as the youth pleased him, he said: "You may ask for three things to take into the castle with you, but they must be things without life."

author: Grimms
text: Then he answered: "Then I ask for a fire, a turning lathe, and a cutting-board with the knife."

author: Grimms
text: The king had these things carried into the castle for him during the day.

author: Grimms
text: When night was drawing near, the youth went up and made himself a bright fire in one of the rooms, placed the cutting-board and knife beside it, and seated himself by the turning-lathe.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, if I could but shudder!" said he, "but I shall not learn it here either."

author: Grimms
text: Towards midnight he was about to poke his fire, and as he was blowing it, something cried suddenly from one corner: "Au, miau! how cold we are!"

author: Grimms
text: "You fools!" cried he, "what are you crying about?

author: Grimms
text: If you are cold, come and take a seat by the fire and warm yourselves."

author: Grimms
text: And when he had said that, two great black cats came with one tremendous leap and sat down on each side of him, and looked savagely at him with their fiery eyes.

author: Grimms
text: After a short time, when they had warmed themselves, they said: "Comrade, shall we have a game of cards?"

author: Grimms
text: "Why not?" he replied, "but just show me your paws."

author: Grimms
text: Then they stretched out their claws.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh," said he, "what long nails you have!

author: Grimms
text: Wait, I must first cut them for you."

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon he seized them by the throats, put them on the cutting-board and screwed their feet fast.

author: Grimms
text: "I have looked at your fingers," said he, "and my fancy for card-playing has gone," and he struck them dead and threw them out into the water.

author: Grimms
text: But when he had made away with these two, and was about to sit down again by his fire, out from every hole and corner came black cats and black dogs with red-hot chains, and more and more of them came until he could no longer move, and they yelled horribly, and got on his fire, pulled it to pieces, and tried to put it out.

author: Grimms
text: He watched them for a while quietly, but at last when they were going too far, he seized his cutting-knife, and cried: "Away with you, vermin," and began to cut them down.

author: Grimms
text: Some of them ran away, the others he killed, and threw out into the fish-pond.

author: Grimms
text: When he came back he fanned the embers of his fire again and warmed himself.

author: Grimms
text: And as he thus sat, his eyes would keep open no longer, and he felt a desire to sleep.

author: Grimms
text: Then he looked round and saw a great bed in the corner.

author: Grimms
text: "That is the very thing for me," said he, and got into it.

author: Grimms
text: When he was just going to shut his eyes, however, the bed began to move of its own accord, and went over the whole of the castle.

author: Grimms
text: "That"s right," said he, "but go faster."

author: Grimms
text: Then the bed rolled on as if six horses were harnessed to it, up and down, over thresholds and stairs, but suddenly hop, hop, it turned over upside down, and lay on him like a mountain.

author: Grimms
text: But he threw quilts and pillows up in the air, got out and said: "Now anyone who likes, may drive," and lay down by his fire, and slept till it was day.

author: Grimms
text: In the morning the king came, and when he saw him lying there on the ground, he thought the evil spirits had killed him and he was dead.

author: Grimms
text: Then said he: "After all it is a pity,--for so handsome a man."

author: Grimms
text: The youth heard it, got up, and said: "It has not come to that yet."

author: Grimms
text: Then the king was astonished, but very glad, and asked how he had fared.

author: Grimms
text: "Very well indeed," answered he; "one night is past, the two others will pass likewise."

author: Grimms
text: Then he went to the innkeeper, who opened his eyes very wide, and said: "I never expected to see you alive again!

author: Grimms
text: Have you learnt how to shudder yet?"

author: Grimms
text: "No," said he, "it is all in vain.

author: Grimms
text: If someone would but tell me!"

author: Grimms
text: The second night he again went up into the old castle, sat down by the fire, and once more began his old song: "If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: When midnight came, an uproar and noise of tumbling about was heard; at first it was low, but it grew louder and louder.

author: Grimms
text: Then it was quiet for a while, and at length with a loud scream, half a man came down the chimney and fell before him.

author: Grimms
text: "Hullo!" cried he, "another half belongs to this.

author: Grimms
text: This is not enough!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the uproar began again, there was a roaring and howling, and the other half fell down likewise.

author: Grimms
text: "Wait," said he, "I will just stoke up the fire a little for you."

author: Grimms
text: When he had done that and looked round again, the two pieces were joined together, and a hideous man was sitting in his place.

author: Grimms
text: "That is no part of our bargain," said the youth, "the bench is mine."

author: Grimms
text: The man wanted to push him away; the youth, however, would not allow that, but thrust him off with all his strength, and seated himself again in his own place.

author: Grimms
text: Then still more men fell down, one after the other; they brought nine dead men"s legs and two skulls, and set them up and played at nine-pins with them.

author: Grimms
text: The youth also wanted to play and said: "Listen you, can I join you?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, if you have any money."

author: Grimms
text: "Money enough," replied he, "but your balls are not quite round."

author: Grimms
text: Then he took the skulls and put them in the lathe and turned them till they were round.

author: Grimms
text: "There, now they will roll better!" said he.

author: Grimms
text: "Hurrah! now we"ll have fun!"

author: Grimms
text: He played with them and lost some of his money, but when it struck twelve, everything vanished from his sight.

author: Grimms
text: He lay down and quietly fell asleep.

author: Grimms
text: Next morning the king came to inquire after him.

author: Grimms
text: "How has it fared with you this time?" asked he.

author: Grimms
text: "I have been playing at ninepins," he answered, "and have lost a couple of farthings."

author: Grimms
text: "Have you not shuddered then?"

author: Grimms
text: "What?" said he, "I have had a wonderful time!

author: Grimms
text: If I did but know what it was to shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: The third night he sat down again on his bench and said quite sadly: "If I could but shudder."

author: Grimms
text: When it grew late, six tall men came in and brought a coffin.

author: Grimms
text: Then he said: "Ha, ha, that is certainly my little cousin, who died only a few days ago," and he beckoned with his finger, and cried: "Come, little cousin, come."

author: Grimms
text: They placed the coffin on the ground, but he went to it and took the lid off, and a dead man lay therein.

author: Grimms
text: He felt his face, but it was cold as ice.

author: Grimms
text: "Wait," said he, "I will warm you a little," and went to the fire and warmed his hand and laid it on the dead man"s face, but he remained cold.

author: Grimms
text: Then he took him out, and sat down by the fire and laid him on his breast and rubbed his arms that the blood might circulate again.

author: Grimms
text: As this also did no good, he thought to himself: "When two people lie in bed together, they warm each other," and carried him to the bed, covered him over and lay down by him.

author: Grimms
text: After a short time the dead man became warm too, and began to move.

author: Grimms
text: Then said the youth, "See, little cousin, have I not warmed you?"

author: Grimms
text: The dead man, however, got up and cried: "Now will I strangle you."

author: Grimms
text: "What!" said he, "is that the way you thank me?

author: Grimms
text: You shall at once go into your coffin again," and he took him up, threw him into it, and shut the lid.

author: Grimms
text: Then came the six men and carried him away again.

author: Grimms
text: "I cannot manage to shudder," said he.

author: Grimms
text: "I shall never learn it here as long as I live."

author: Grimms
text: Then a man entered who was taller than all others, and looked terrible.

author: Grimms
text: He was old, however, and had a long white beard.

author: Grimms
text: "You wretch," cried he, "you shall soon learn what it is to shudder, for you shall die."

author: Grimms
text: "Not so fast," replied the youth.

author: Grimms
text: "If I am to die, I shall have to have a say in it."

author: Grimms
text: "I will soon seize you," said the fiend.

author: Grimms
text: "Softly, softly, do not talk so big.

author: Grimms
text: I am as strong as you are, and perhaps even stronger."

author: Grimms
text: "We shall see," said the old man.

author: Grimms
text: "If you are stronger, I will let you go--come, we will try."

author: Grimms
text: Then he led him by dark passages to a smith"s forge, took an axe, and with one blow struck an anvil into the ground.

author: Grimms
text: "I can do better than that," said the youth, and went to the other anvil.

author: Grimms
text: The old man placed himself near and wanted to look on, and his white beard hung down.

author: Grimms
text: Then the youth seized the axe, split the anvil with one blow, and in it caught the old man"s beard.

author: Grimms
text: "Now I have you," said the youth.

author: Grimms
text: "Now it is your turn to die."

author: Grimms
text: Then he seized an iron bar and beat the old man till he moaned and entreated him to stop, when he would give him great riches.

author: Grimms
text: The youth drew out the axe and let him go.

author: Grimms
text: The old man led him back into the castle, and in a cellar showed him three chests full of gold.

author: Grimms
text: "Of these," said he, "one part is for the poor, the other for the king, the third yours."

author: Grimms
text: In the meantime it struck twelve, and the spirit disappeared, so that the youth stood in darkness.

author: Grimms
text: "I shall still be able to find my way out," said he, and felt about, found the way into the room, and slept there by his fire.

author: Grimms
text: Next morning the king came and said: "Now you must have learnt what shuddering is?"

author: Grimms
text: "No," he answered; "what can it be?

author: Grimms
text: My dead cousin was here, and a bearded man came and showed me a great deal of money down below, but no one told me what it was to shudder."

author: Grimms
text: "Then," said the king, "you have saved the castle, and shall marry my daughter."

author: Grimms
text: "That is all very well," said he, "but still I do not know what it is to shudder!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the gold was brought up and the wedding celebrated; but howsoever much the young king loved his wife, and however happy he was, he still said always: "If I could but shudder--if I could but shudder."

author: Grimms
text: And this at last angered her.

author: Grimms
text: Her waiting-maid said: "I will find a cure for him; he shall soon learn what it is to shudder."

author: Grimms
text: She went out to the stream which flowed through the garden, and had a whole bucketful of gudgeons brought to her.

author: Grimms
text: At night when the young king was sleeping, his wife was to draw the clothes off him and empty the bucket full of cold water with the gudgeons in it over him, so that the little fishes would sprawl about him.

author: Grimms
text: Then he woke up and cried: "Oh, what makes me shudder so?-- what makes me shudder so, dear wife?

author: Grimms
text: Ah! now I know what it is to shudder!"
